summary: This is a motion filed by attorneys for the independent administrator of the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) to quash a subpoena from Ghislaine Maxwell seeking documents related to four victims. The motion argues that compliance would violate the program's foundational promise of confidentiality, that the sought materials are inadmissible under Federal Rule of Evidence 408, and that they constitute witness statements not subject to subpoena under Rule 17(h).

persons.name: Patrick J. Smith
persons.context: Attorney from Smith Villazor LLP who signed and submitted the motion to quash Ghislaine Maxwell's subpoena directed at the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the United States v. Maxwell case to whom the motion is addressed.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case who issued the subpoena seeking documents from the EVCP concerning four victims.

persons.name: Kenneth R. Feinberg
persons.context: A nationally recognized claims-administration expert who helped design the EVCP and testified about its confidentiality protections.

persons.name: Camille S. Biros
persons.context: A nationally recognized claims-administration expert who, with Kenneth Feinberg, helped design and administer the EVCP.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The deceased individual whose estate established the EVCP to resolve claims of sexual abuse against him and related entities.

connections.description: Colleagues who jointly designed and administered the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program and other large-scale compensation programs.
Maxwell is a defendant in a case related to Epstein's activities, and the EVCP was created to resolve claims against Epstein and related individuals.
Smith, representing the EVCP administrator, is legally opposing Maxwell's subpoena in court.

events.title: Proposal of Epstein Victims' Compensation Program
events.description: The co-executors of Epstein's estate sought court approval to create a voluntary claims resolution program for victims.

events.title: EVCP Court Approval
events.description: The U.S. Virgin Islands probate court approved the Epstein Victims' Compensation Program as designed.

events.title: EVCP Commencement
events.description: The EVCP announced that individuals could begin filing claims for compensation.

events.title: EVCP Concludes Claimant Operations
events.description: The EVCP announced it had concluded its claimant-facing operations, having awarded nearly $125 million to approximately 150 eligible claimants.

events.title: Maxwell's Subpoena Motion
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell filed a motion seeking authorization to serve a subpoena on the EVCP administrator for documents concerning four victims.

locations: 250 West 55th Street, 30th Floor, New York, New York 10019
40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: The Epstein Victims' Compensation Program (EVCP) was a court-approved, confidential program established to resolve claims of sexual abuse against Jeffrey Epstein, his estate, and related parties.
Confidentiality was described as a 'cornerstone' and of 'paramount importance' to the EVCP, with assurances given to victims to encourage participation.
As of August 2021, the EVCP had awarded nearly $125 million to approximately 150 eligible claimants, with 92% accepting their offers.
Ghislaine Maxwell sought a subpoena for EVCP documents related to four specific victims, including claim forms, communications, payment records, and releases.
The motion to quash argues the subpoena is unreasonable/oppressive, seeks inadmissible settlement evidence under Rule 408, and seeks protected witness statements under Rule 17(h).
